message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Ergodicity Breaking Arising from Hilbert Space Fragmentation in Dipole-Conserving Hamiltonians
Paper Abstract: We show that the combination of charge and dipole conservation---characteristic of fracton systems---leads to an extensive fragmentation of the Hilbert space, which in turn can lead to a breakdown of thermalization. As a concrete example, we investigate the out-of-equilibrium dynamics of one-dimensional spin-1 models that conserve charge (total $S^z$) and its associated dipole moment. First, we consider a minimal model including only three-site terms and find that the infinite temperature auto-correlation saturates to a finite value---showcasing non-thermal behavior. The absence of thermalization is identified as a consequence of the strong fragmentation of the Hilbert space into exponentially many invariant subspaces in the local $S^z$ basis, arising from the interplay of dipole conservation and local interactions. Second, we extend the model by including four-site terms and find that this perturbation leads to a weak fragmentation: the system still has exponentially many invariant subspaces, but they are no longer sufficient to avoid thermalization for typical initial states. More generally, for any finite range of interactions, the system still exhibits non-thermal eigenstates appearing throughout the entire spectrum. We compare our results to charge and dipole moment conserving random unitary circuit models for which we reach identical conclusions.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Hilbert spaces:

## Definition

A Hilbert space is a real or complex inner product space that is also a complete metric space with respect to the metric induced by the inner product.(no content)It generalizes the notion of Euclidean space to infinite dimensions.

## Key Properties

The inner product, which is the analog of the dot product from vector calculus, allows lengths and angles to be defined.(no content)Furthermore, completeness means that there are enough limits in the space to allow the techniques of calculus to be used.

## Historical Background

Hilbert spaces were studied beginning in the first decade of the 20th century by David Hilbert, Erhard Schmidt, and Frigyes Riesz.(no content)John von Neumann coined the term Hilbert space for the abstract concept that underlies many of these diverse applications.

## Applications

They are indispensable tools in the theories of partial differential equations, quantum mechanics, Fourier analysis (which includes applications to signal processing and heat transfer), and ergodic theory (which forms the mathematical underpinning of thermodynamics).(no content)In quantum mechanics, the states of a quantum mechanical system are vectors in a certain Hilbert space, the observables are hermitian operators on that space, the symmetries of the system are unitary operators, and measurements are orthogonal projections.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

The inner product, which is the analog of the dot product from vector calculus, allows lengths and angles to be defined.(no content)Furthermore, completeness means that there are enough limits in the space to allow the techniques of calculus to be used.

## Historical Background

Hilbert spaces were studied beginning in the first decade of the 20th century by David Hilbert, Erhard Schmidt, and Frigyes Riesz.(no content)John von Neumann coined the term Hilbert space for the abstract concept that underlies many of these diverse applications.

## Applications

They are indispensable tools in the theories of partial differential equations, quantum mechanics, Fourier analysis (which includes applications to signal processing and heat transfer), and ergodic theory (which forms the mathematical underpinning of thermodynamics).(no content)In quantum mechanics, the states of a quantum mechanical system are vectors in a certain Hilbert space, the observables are hermitian operators on that space, the symmetries of the system are unitary operators, and measurements are orthogonal projections.

Here's an overview of random matrix theory and its applications in quantum mechanics:

## Definition and Basics

A random matrix is a matrix-valued random variable, and random matrix theory (RMT) is the study of properties of random matrices, often as they become large.

## Quantum Applications

Random matrix theory plays several important roles in quantum physics:

**Quantum Chaos:** In quantum chaos, the Bohigas–Giannoni–Schmit (BGS) conjecture asserts that the spectral statistics of quantum systems whose classical counterparts exhibit chaotic behaviour are described by random matrix theory.(no content)For systems invariant under time reversal, the energy-level statistics of a number of chaotic systems have been shown to be in good agreement with the predictions of the Gaussian orthogonal ensemble (GOE) of random matrices.

**Quantum Optics:** In quantum optics, transformations described by random unitary matrices are crucial for demonstrating the advantage of quantum over classical computation (see, e.g., the boson sampling model).

## Physical Relevance

Many physical phenomena, such as the spectrum of nuclei of heavy atoms, the thermal conductivity of a lattice, or the emergence of quantum chaos, can be modeled mathematically as problems concerning large, random matrices.(no content)Random matrix theory first gained attention beyond mathematics literature in the context of nuclear physics.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Thermalisation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermalisation"},{"title":"Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenstate_thermalization_hypothesis"},{"title":"Many-body localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Many-body_localization"},{"title":"Two temperature model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two_temperature_model"},{"title":"David A. Huse - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_A._Huse"},{"title":"Thermal physics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermal_physics"},{"title":"Statistical mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_mechanics"},{"title":"Stochastic thermodynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draft:Stochastic_Thermodynamics"},{"title":"Thermal fluctuations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermal_fluctuation"},{"title":"Quantum thermodynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_thermodynamics"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about thermalization in statistical mechanics:

## Overview

Thermalization is the process of physical bodies reaching thermal equilibrium through mutual interaction.(no content)The natural tendency of a system is towards a state of equipartition of energy and uniform temperature that maximizes the system's entropy.

## Key Concept: Eigenstate Thermalization Hypothesis

The eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH) is a set of ideas which purports to explain when and why an isolated quantum mechanical system can be accurately described using equilibrium statistical mechanics.(no content)It is devoted to understanding how systems which are initially prepared in far-from-equilibrium states can evolve in time to a state which appears to be in thermal equilibrium.

## Exceptions to Thermalization

Not all systems thermalize. Many-body localization (MBL) involves quantum many-body systems retaining memory of their initial condition in local observables for arbitrary amounts of time.(no content)Quantum integrable systems and systems with dynamical symmetries also resist thermalisation.

## Historical Context

The phrase "eigenstate thermalization" was first coined by Mark Srednicki in 1994, after similar ideas had been introduced by Josh Deutsch in 1991.

The study of thermalization in isolated quantum systems remains an active area of research, particularly regarding when and why systems approach thermal equilibrium without external interaction with an environment.

Links: [{"title":"Conservation law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_law"},{"title":"Conservation of energy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_of_energy"},{"title":"Conserved current - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conserved_current"},{"title":"Conservation of mass - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_of_mass"},{"title":"Talk:Conservation law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Conservation_law"},{"title":"Newton's laws of motion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton's_laws_of_motion"},{"title":"First law of thermodynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_law_of_thermodynamics"},{"title":"Fluid dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fluid_dynamics"},{"title":"Totalitarian principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Totalitarian_principle"},{"title":"Scientific law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_law"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of conservation laws in physics:

## Definition and Fundamentals

In physics, a conservation law states that a particular measurable property of an isolated physical system does not change as the system evolves over time.(no content)Conservation laws are fundamental to our understanding of the physical world, in that they describe which processes can or cannot occur in nature.

## Examples of Conservation Laws

Exact conservation laws include conservation of mass-energy, conservation of linear momentum, conservation of angular momentum, and conservation of electric charge. Additionally, there are also many approximate conservation laws, which apply to such quantities as mass, parity, lepton number, baryon number, strangeness, hypercharge, etc.

## Mathematical Expression

A local conservation law is usually expressed mathematically as a continuity equation, a partial differential equation which gives a relation between the amount of the quantity and the "transport" of that quantity.

## Connection to Symmetry

One particularly important result concerning local conservation laws is Noether's theorem, which states that there is a one-to-one correspondence between each one of them and a differentiable symmetry of the Universe. For example, the local conservation of energy follows from the uniformity of time and the local conservation of angular momentum arises from the isotropy of space, i.e. because there is no preferred direction of space.

## Broad Applications

Conservation laws are considered to be fundamental laws of nature, with broad application in physics, as well as in other fields such as chemistry, biology, geology, and engineering.

Links: [{"title":"Conservation law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_law"},{"title":"Conservation of energy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_of_energy"},{"title":"Conserved current - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conserved_current"},{"title":"Conservation of mass - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_of_mass"},{"title":"Talk:Conservation law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Conservation_law"},{"title":"Newton's laws of motion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton's_laws_of_motion"},{"title":"First law of thermodynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_law_of_thermodynamics"},{"title":"Fluid dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fluid_dynamics"},{"title":"Totalitarian principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Totalitarian_principle"},{"title":"Scientific law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_law"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of conservation laws in physics:

## Definition and Fundamentals

In physics, a conservation law states that a particular measurable property of an isolated physical system does not change as the system evolves over time.(no content)Conservation laws are fundamental to our understanding of the physical world, in that they describe which processes can or cannot occur in nature.

## Examples of Conservation Laws

Exact conservation laws include conservation of mass-energy, conservation of linear momentum, conservation of angular momentum, and conservation of electric charge. Additionally, there are also many approximate conservation laws, which apply to such quantities as mass, parity, lepton number, baryon number, strangeness, hypercharge, etc.

## Mathematical Expression

A local conservation law is usually expressed mathematically as a continuity equation, a partial differential equation which gives a relation between the amount of the quantity and the "transport" of that quantity.

## Connection to Symmetry

One particularly important result concerning local conservation laws is Noether's theorem, which states that there is a one-to-one correspondence between each one of them and a differentiable symmetry of the Universe. For example, the local conservation of energy follows from the uniformity of time and the local conservation of angular momentum arises from the isotropy of space, i.e. because there is no preferred direction of space.

## Broad Applications

Conservation laws are considered to be fundamental laws of nature, with broad application in physics, as well as in other fields such as chemistry, biology, geology, and engineering.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of quantum many-body physics:

## Definition

The quantum many-body problem is a general name for a vast category of physical problems pertaining to deriving the behavior of multi-particle systems using fundamental quantum-mechanical principles.

## Key Challenges

One of the fundamental challenges in this field is computational complexity. In quantum mechanics, the dimension of the many-body wave function scales exponentially with the number of particles, making simulating the dynamics of more than three quantum-mechanical particles already infeasible for many physical systems. As a result, many-body physics most often relies on a set ofapproximation methods, such as the variational method and perturbation theory, specific to the problem at hand.(no content)It ranks among the most computationally intensive fields of science.

## Importance

Many-body problems play a central role in condensed matter physics.

## Mathematical Tools

Creation and annihilation operators are fundamental to quantum many-body theory, as every many-body operator (including the Hamiltonian of the many-body system and all the physical observables) can be expressed in terms of them. Second quantization, also referred to as occupation number representation, is a formalism used to describe and analyze quantum many-body systems.

Links: [{"title":"Hamiltonian mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_mechanics"},{"title":"Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_(quantum_mechanics)"},{"title":"Category:Hamiltonian mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Hamiltonian_mechanics"},{"title":"Hamiltonian fluid mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_fluid_mechanics"},{"title":"Lagrangian mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrangian_mechanics"},{"title":"Relativistic Lagrangian mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relativistic_Lagrangian_mechanics"},{"title":"Hamiltonian (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Hamiltonian system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_system"},{"title":"Hamiltonian field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_field_theory"},{"title":"Hamilton's principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamilton's_principle"}]

Based on the search results, here's what you should know about Hamiltonian mechanics:

## Overview

Hamiltonian mechanics is a reformulation of Lagrangian mechanics that emerged in 1833.(no content)Introduced by Sir William Rowan Hamilton, Hamiltonian mechanics replaces (generalized) velocities used in Lagrangian mechanics with (generalized) momenta.

## Key Concepts

Any smooth real-valued function H on a symplectic manifold can be used to define a Hamiltonian system. The function H is known as "the Hamiltonian" or "the energy function." The symplectic manifold is then called the phase space.(no content)A simple interpretation comes from its application on a one-dimensional system consisting of one nonrelativistic particle: the value of the Hamiltonian is the total energy of the system, in this case the sum of kinetic and potential energy.

## Physical Systems and Applications

A Hamiltonian system is a dynamical system governed by Hamilton's equations. In physics, this dynamical system describes the evolution of a physical system such as a planetary system or an electron in an electromagnetic field.

## Relationship to Other Frameworks

Both theories provide interpretations of classical mechanics and describe the same physical phenomena. Hamiltonian mechanics has a close relationship with geometry (notably, symplectic geometry and Poisson structures) and serves as a link between classical and quantum mechanics.

Links: [{"title":"Fracton (subdimensional particle) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fracton_(subdimensional_particle)"},{"title":"Topological order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_order"},{"title":"Topological sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_sorting"},{"title":"Fracton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fracton"},{"title":"Symmetry-protected topological order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry-protected_topological_order"},{"title":"Fractal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractals"},{"title":"Fractional quantum Hall effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractional_quantum_Hall_effect"},{"title":"Fractional Chern insulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractional_Chern_insulator"},{"title":"Topological defect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_defect"},{"title":"Topological quantum field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_quantum_field_theory"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about fracton topological order:

## What are Fractons?

A fracton is an emergent topological quasiparticle excitation which is immobile when in isolation.(no content)Many theoretical systems have been proposed in which fractons exist as elementary excitations. Such systems are known as fracton models.

## Key Characteristics of Fracton Models

Gapped fracton models often feature a topological ground state degeneracy that grows exponentially and sub-extensively with system size. One important distinction is that fracton models do not have the property that ground state degeneracy depends only on the topology of the manifold; the ground state degeneracy also depends on system size.

## Classification

Among the gapped phases of fracton models, there is a non-rigorous phenomenological classification into "type I" and "type II". Type I fracton models generally have fracton excitations that are completely immobile, as well as other excitations, including bound states, with restricted mobility. Type II fracton models generally have fracton excitations and no mobile particles of any form.

## Foliated Fracton Order

The concept of foliated fracton order resolves issues with phase equivalence, by allowing degenerate subsystems (two-dimensional gapped topological phases) to be used as "free resources" that can be arbitrarily added or removed from the system.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Foliated Fracton Order

The concept of foliated fracton order resolves issues with phase equivalence, by allowing degenerate subsystems (two-dimensional gapped topological phases) to be used as "free resources" that can be arbitrarily added or removed from the system.

Here are the search results for "Spin model quantum":

## Overview

A quantum spin model is a quantum Hamiltonian model that describes a system which consists of spins either interacting or not and are an active area of research in the fields of strongly correlated electron systems, quantum information theory, and quantum computing.(no content)The physical observables in these quantum models are operators in a Hilbert space acting on state vectors as opposed to the physical observables in the corresponding classical spin models - like the Ising model - which are commutative variables.

## Key Examples

**Quantum Heisenberg Model:** The quantum Heisenberg model, developed by Werner Heisenberg, is a statistical mechanical model used in the study of critical points and phase transitions of magnetic systems, in which the spins of the magnetic systems are treated quantum mechanically.

**Spin Chains:** A spin chain is a type of model in statistical physics. Spin chains were originally formulated to model magnetic systems, which typically consist of particles with magnetic spin located at fixed sites on a lattice.

**Transverse Field Ising Model:** The transverse field Ising model is a quantum version of the classical Ising model. It features a lattice with nearest neighbour interactions determined by the alignment or anti-alignment of spin projections along the z axis, as well as an external magnetic field perpendicular to the z axis.

## Applications

In the context of quantum computation, it represents a qubit coupled to an environment, which can produce decoherence, and represents a paradigm in the study of quantum phase transitions.

Web search results for query: "Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis"

Links: [{"title":"Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenstate_thermalization_hypothesis"},{"title":"Thermalisation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermalisation"},{"title":"Quantum thermodynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_thermodynamics"},{"title":"Talk:Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Eigenstate_thermalization_hypothesis"},{"title":"Krishnendu Sengupta - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krishnendu_Sengupta"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Teahouse/Questions/Archive 145 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Teahouse/Questions/Archive_145"},{"title":"Category:Thermodynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Thermodynamics"},{"title":"Fundamental thermodynamic relation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combined_law_of_thermodynamics"},{"title":"Two temperature model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two_temperature_model"},{"title":"Helmholtz free energy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helmholtz_free_energy"}]

## Eigenstate Thermalization Hypothesis

The eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH) is a set of ideas which purports to explain when and why an isolated quantum mechanical system can be accurately described using equilibrium statistical mechanics.(no content)It is devoted to understanding how systems which are initially prepared in far-from-equilibrium states can evolve in time to a state which appears to be in thermal equilibrium.

### History

The phrase "eigenstate thermalization" was first coined by Mark Srednicki in 1994, after similar ideas had been introduced by Josh Deutsch in 1991.

### Core Concepts

The principal philosophy underlying the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis is that instead of explaining the ergodicity of a thermodynamic system through the mechanism of dynamical chaos, as is done in classical mechanics, one should instead examine the properties of matrix elements of observable quantities in individual energy eigenstates of the system.

According to the ETH, for an arbitrary initial state, the expectation value of an observable will ultimately evolve in time to its value predicted by a microcanonical ensemble, and thereafter will exhibit only small fluctuations around that value, provided that certain conditions are met.

### Current Status

There is no known analytical derivation of the eigenstate thermalization hypothesis for general interacting systems. However, it has been verified to be true for a wide variety of interacting systems using numerical exact diagonalization techniques, to within the uncertainty of these methods.(no content)It is also known to explicitly fail in certain integrable systems, in which the presence of a large number of constants of motion prevent thermalization.

Links: [{"title":"Ergodicity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodicity"},{"title":"Ergodicity economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodicity_economics"},{"title":"Quantum ergodicity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_ergodicity"},{"title":"Ergodic hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_hypothesis"},{"title":"Ergodic theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_theory"},{"title":"Ergodic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_process"},{"title":"Stationary ergodic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stationary_ergodic_process"},{"title":"Ergodic literature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_literature"},{"title":"Kingman's subadditive ergodic theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingman's_subadditive_ergodic_theorem"},{"title":"Mixing (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixing_(mathematics)"}]

Here are the search results for **Ergodicity**:

## Overview

Ergodicity is a property of the system; it is a statement that the system cannot be reduced or factored into smaller components.(no content)Ergodic theory is the study of systems possessing ergodicity.

## Key Concepts

Ergodicity implies that the average behaviour along a single trajectory through time (time average) is equivalent to the average behaviour of a large ensemble at one point in time (ensemble average).(no content)Ergodic systems capture the common-sense, everyday notions of randomness, such that smoke might come to fill all of a smoke-filled room, or that a block of metal might eventually come to have the same temperature throughout, or that flips of a fair coin may come up heads and tails half the time.

## Historical Origins

The origins of ergodicity lie in statistical physics, where Ludwig Boltzmann formulated the ergodic hypothesis.

## Mathematical Foundation

The proper mathematical formulation of ergodicity is founded on the formal definitions of measure theory and dynamical systems, and rather specifically on the notion of a measure-preserving dynamical system.

## Applications

Ergodic systems occur in a broad range of systems in physics and in geometry. The concept has applications spanning from quantum mechanics to economics, with emerging fields like ergodicity economics examining the implications when systems are non-ergodic.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Ergodic systems occur in a broad range of systems in physics and in geometry. The concept has applications spanning from quantum mechanics to economics, with emerging fields like ergodicity economics examining the implications when systems are non-ergodic.

Web search results for query: "Dipole moment"

Links: [{"title":"Dipole moment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dipole_moment"},{"title":"Neutron electric dipole moment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neutron_electric_dipole_moment"},{"title":"Transition dipole moment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transition_dipole_moment"},{"title":"Anomalous magnetic dipole moment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anomalous_magnetic_dipole_moment"},{"title":"Electron electric dipole moment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electron_electric_dipole_moment"},{"title":"Electric dipole moment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_dipole_moment"},{"title":"Chemical polarity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org//wiki/Bond_dipole_moment"},{"title":"Dipole - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dipole"},{"title":"File:Propane-dipole-moment-2D.png","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Propane-dipole-moment-2D.png"},{"title":"Nuclear electric dipole moment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_electric_dipole_moment"}]

## Overview of Dipole Moment

The term "dipole moment" refers to several different concepts in physics and chemistry. Here are the main types:

### Electric Dipole Moment

The electric dipole moment is a measure of the separation of positive and negative electrical charges within a system: that is, a measure of the system's overall polarity.(no content)The SI unit for electric dipole moment is the coulomb-metre (C⋅m).

### Molecular and Bond Dipole Moments

The bond dipole moment is calculated by multiplying the amount of charge separated and the distance between the charges.(no content)The overall dipole moment of a molecule may be approximated as a vector sum of bond dipole moments. As a vector sum it depends on the relative orientation of the bonds, so that from the dipole moment information can be deduced about the molecular geometry.

### Magnetic Dipole Moment

The magnetic moment, also called magnetic dipole moment, is a measure of the strength of a magnetic source.

### Other Types

Dipole moment may refer to: Electric dipole moment, the measure of the electrical polarity of a system of charges · Transition dipole moment, the electrical dipole moment in quantum mechanics · Molecular dipole moment, the electric dipole moment of a molecule · Bond dipole moment, the measure of polarity of a chemical bond · Electron electric dipole moment, the measure of the charge distribution within an electron · Magnetic dipole moment, the measure of the magnetic polarity of a system of charges among others.

Links: [{"title":"Quantum dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_dynamics"},{"title":"Quantum brain dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_brain_dynamics"},{"title":"Quantum hydrodynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_hydrodynamics"},{"title":"Quantum mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_mechanics"},{"title":"Quantum electrodynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_electrodynamics"},{"title":"Quantum Monte Carlo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Monte_Carlo"},{"title":"Observer (quantum physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer_(quantum_physics)"},{"title":"Attosecond physics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attosecond_physics"},{"title":"Continuous spontaneous localization model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_spontaneous_localization_model"},{"title":"Open quantum system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_quantum_system"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about quantum dynamics:

## Overview

Quantum dynamics is the quantum version of classical dynamics that deals with the motions, and energy and momentum exchanges of systems whose behavior is governed by the laws of quantum mechanics.(no content)Quantum dynamics is relevant for burgeoning fields, such as quantum computing and atomic optics.

## Key Principles

While quantum dynamics is fundamentally different from classical dynamics, it is also a generalization of it, with the principles of classical mechanics emerging from quantum mechanics as an approximation in the macroscopic limit.

A major difference from classical physics is in how variables are represented: In quantum dynamics, variables are represented by operators (q-numbers) which, crucially, do not necessarily commute.(no content)This non-commutativity is the source of the Heisenberg uncertainty principle and fundamentally alters the dynamics of a system, making it impossible to simultaneously know the precise position and momentum of a particle.

## Governing Equations

The dynamics of a quantum system are governed by a specific equation of motion that depends on whether the system is considered closed (isolated from its environment) or open (coupled to an environment).

For closed systems, the most common formulation of quantum dynamics is the time-dependent Schrödinger equation.

For open quantum systems, the dynamics are typically modeled using quantum master equations, with the most general form for a system whose environment has no memory being the Lindblad equation.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Invariant subspace linear algebra"

Links: [{"title":"Invariant subspace - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Invariant_subspace"},{"title":"Invariant subspace problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Invariant_subspace_problem"},{"title":"Lomonosov's invariant subspace theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lomonosov's_invariant_subspace_theorem"},{"title":"Linear subspace - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_subspace"},{"title":"Reducing subspace - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reducing_subspace"},{"title":"Jordan normal form - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_normal_form"},{"title":"Invariant theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Invariant_tensor"},{"title":"Category:Invariant subspaces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Invariant_subspaces"},{"title":"Invariant (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Invariant_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Lie algebra representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lie_algebra_representation"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about invariant subspaces in linear algebra:

## Definition

An invariant subspace of a linear mapping T is a subspace W of V that is preserved by T. More generally, an invariant subspace for a collection of linear mappings is a subspace preserved by each mapping individually.

## Key Properties

**Connection to Eigenvectors:** Any eigenvector for T spans a 1-dimensional invariant subspace, and vice-versa. More specifically, if U is a 1-dimensional invariant subspace for operator T with vector v ∈ U, then the vectors v and Tv must be linearly dependent.

**Existence in Finite Dimensions:** As a consequence of the fundamental theorem of algebra, every linear operator on a nonzero finite-dimensional complex vector space has an eigenvector. Therefore, every such linear operator in at least two dimensions has a proper non-trivial invariant subspace.

## The Invariant Subspace Problem

The invariant subspace problem concerns the case where V is a separable Hilbert space over the complex numbers, of dimension > 1, and T is a bounded operator. The problem is to decide whether every such T has a non-trivial, closed, invariant subspace. It is unsolved.

However, Aronszajn & Smith (1954) proved that every compact operator on any Banach space of dimension at least 2 has an invariant subspace.

However, Aronszajn & Smith (1954) proved that every compact operator on any Banach space of dimension at least 2 has an invariant subspace.

Based on the search results, here's information about invariant subspaces in linear algebra:

## Definition

An invariant subspace of a linear mapping T is a subspace W of V that is preserved by T. More generally, an invariant subspace for a collection of linear mappings is a subspace preserved by each mapping individually.

## Key Properties

**Connection to Eigenvectors:** Any eigenvector for T spans a 1-dimensional invariant subspace, and vice-versa. More specifically, if U is a 1-dimensional invariant subspace for operator T with vector v ∈ U, then the vectors v and Tv must be linearly dependent.

**Existence in Finite Dimensions:** As a consequence of the fundamental theorem of algebra, every linear operator on a nonzero finite-dimensional complex vector space has an eigenvector. Therefore, every such linear operator in at least two dimensions has a proper non-trivial invariant subspace.

## The Invariant Subspace Problem

The invariant subspace problem concerns the case where V is a separable Hilbert space over the complex numbers, of dimension > 1, and T is a bounded operator. The problem is to decide whether every such T has a non-trivial, closed, invariant subspace. It is unsolved.

However, Aronszajn & Smith (1954) proved that every compact operator on any Banach space of dimension at least 2 has an invariant subspace.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name (Wikipedia article title), relation (uses or proposes), entity_type (task/method/data/artifact/tool/concept/other), wikipedia_url (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance (1 sentence)

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Ergodicity Breaking Arising from Hilbert Space Fragmentation in Dipole-Conserving Hamiltonians". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Key Technologies and Methodologies Identified:**

1. **Hilbert space** (concept, uses) - Mathematical framework for quantum states
2. **Ergodicity** (concept, proposes) - Central result: ergodicity breaking
3. **Conservation law** (concept, uses) - Charge and dipole conservation constraints
4. **Thermalization** (concept, uses) - Breakdown of thermalization studied
5. **Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)** (concept, uses) - Central objects of study
6. **Spin model** (concept, uses) - One-dimensional spin-1 models investigated
7. **Quantum dynamics** (task, uses) - Out-of-equilibrium dynamics analysis
8. **Dipole moment** (concept, uses) - Fracton system constraint
9. **Invariant subspace** (concept, proposes) - Exponentially many invariant subspaces identified
10. **Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis** (concept, uses) - Framework for understanding thermalization failures
11. **Quantum random circuits** (method, uses) - Comparison model for validation
12. **Many-body localization** (concept, uses) - Related phenomenon

**Validation Results:** ✅ All 12 triples passed validation successfully

The paper proposes important new insights about how the interplay between charge and dipole conservation leads to extensive Hilbert space fragmentation, which in turn prevents thermalization and creates non-thermal eigenstates. The work connects fundamental concepts in quantum mechanics with emerging ideas about fragmentation in constrained quantum systems.

Sources:
- [Hilbert space](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilbert_space)
- [Ergodicity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodicity)
- [Conservation law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_law)
- [Thermalisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermalisation)
- [Hamiltonian (quantum mechanics)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamiltonian_(quantum_mechanics))
- [Spin model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_model)
- [Quantum dynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_dynamics)
- [Dipole moment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dipole_moment)
- [Invariant subspace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Invariant_subspace)
- [Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenstate_thermalization_hypothesis)
- [Quantum random circuits](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_random_circuits)
- [Many-body localization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Many-body_localization)
